nl_problem.context: Four boys—Fred, Juan, Marc, and Paul—and three girls—Nita, Rachel, and Trisha—will be assigned to a row of five adjacent lockers, numbered consecutively 1 through 5, arranged along a straight wall. The following conditions govern the assignment of lockers to the seven children: Each locker must be assigned to either one or two children, and each child must be assigned to exactly one locker. Each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy. Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker. Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker. Fred must be assigned to locker 3.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?

declarations: children = EnumSort([Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul, Nita, Rachel, Trisha])
constraints: ForAll([l:lockers], Or(Exists([c:children], assigned(c) == l), Exists([c1:children, c2:children], And(assigned(c1) == l, assigned(c2) == l, c1 != c2))))

ForAll([c1:children, c2:children], Implies(And(assigned(c1) == assigned(c2), c1 != c2), Or(And(c1 in [Nita, Trisha, Rachel], c2 in [Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul]), And(c1 in [Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul], c2 in [Nita, Trisha, Rachel]))))

declarations: children = EnumSort([Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul, Nita, Rachel, Trisha])
constraints: ForAll([i:int], Implies(Count(c, locker(c) == i) == 2, Exists(b, boys, Exists(g, girls, And(locker(b) == i, locker(g) == i)))))
options: is_accurate_list(And(locker(Juan) == locker(Marc), locker(Juan) == locker(Paul), locker(Juan) == locker(Trisha)))
is_accurate_list(And(locker(Juan) == locker(Marc), locker(Juan) == locker(Trisha), locker(Juan) == locker(Nita)))
is_accurate_list(And(locker(Juan) == locker(Nita), locker(Juan) == locker(Trisha), locker(Juan) == locker(Paul)))

If neither type of jazz is on sale, then new pop is. If either type of rap is on sale, then no soul is.

is_sat(And(on_sale(opera, used), on_sale(pop, new), on_sale(pop, used), on_sale(soul, new)))
is_sat(And(on_sale(jazz, used), on_sale(pop, used), on_sale(soul, new), on_sale(soul, used)))

B) Used opera is not on sale.
C) Used rap is not on sale.
D) Neither type of jazz is on sale.
E) Neither type of rap and neither type of soul is on sale.

declarations: cd_types = EnumSort([jazz, opera, pop, rap, soul])
constraints: Implies(And(on_sale(pop, new), on_sale(pop, used)), on_sale(soul, new))
Implies(And(on_sale(jazz, new), on_sale(jazz, used)), Not(on_sale(rap, new)))
Implies(And(Not(on_sale(jazz, new)), Not(on_sale(jazz, used))), on_sale(pop, new))
Implies(Or(on_sale(rap, new), on_sale(rap, used)), Not(on_sale(soul, new)))
options: is_sat(And(Not(on_sale(rap, new)), Not(on_sale(rap, used)), Not(on_sale(soul, new)), Not(on_sale(soul, used))))

declarations: types = EnumSort([jazz, opera, pop, rap, soul])
constraints: Implies(And(onSale(pop, new), onSale(pop, used)), onSale(soul, new))
Implies(And(onSale(jazz, new), onSale(jazz, used)), Not(onSale(rap, new)))
Implies(And(Not(onSale(jazz, new)), Not(onSale(jazz, used))), onSale(pop, new))
Implies(Or(onSale(rap, new), onSale(rap, used)), Not(onSale(soul, new)))
options: is_valid(And(Not(onSale(rap, new)), Not(onSale(rap, used)), Not(onSale(soul, new))))

nl_problem.context: During a single week, from Monday through Friday, tours will be conducted of a company's three divisions—Operations, Production, and Sales. Exactly five tours will be conducted that week, one each day. The schedule of tours for the week must conform to the following restrictions: Each division is toured at least once. The Operations division is not toured on Monday. The Production division is not toured on Wednesday. The Sales division is toured on two consecutive days, and on no other days. If the Operations division is toured on Thursday, then the Production division is toured on Friday.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true of the week's tour schedule?
options: A) The division that is toured on Monday is also toured on Tuesday.
B) The division that is toured on Monday is also toured on Friday.
C) The division that is toured on Tuesday is also toured on Thursday.
D) The division that is toured on Wednesday is also toured on Friday.
E) The division that is toured on Thursday is also toured on Friday.

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
constraints: Exists([day1:days, day2:days], And(day1 != day2, toured(day1) == Sales, toured(day2) == Sales, Abs(day1 - day2) == 1))

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
constraints: Exists([d1:days, d2:days], And(d1 != d2, tour(d1) == Sales, tour(d2) == Sales))

B) Production division is toured on Tuesday and that the Sales division is toured on Wednesday
C) Operations division is toured on Tuesday and that the Production division is toured on Friday
D) Sales division is toured on Monday and that the Operations division is toured on Friday
E) Sales division is toured on Wednesday and that the Production division is toured on Friday

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
constraints: Exists([day1:days, day2:days], And(day1 != day2, And(tours(day1) == Sales, tours(day2) == Sales)))

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
constraints: Exists([day1:days, day2:days], And(day1 != day2, And(tour(day1) == Sales, tour(day2) == Sales)))
ForAll([day:days], Implies(tour(day) == Sales, Not(Exists(day2, And(day2 != day, tour(day2) == Sales)))))

options: A) A tour of the Sales division is scheduled for some day earlier in the week than is any tour of the Production division.
B) A tour of the Operations division is scheduled for some day earlier in the week than is any tour of the Production division.
C) The Sales division is toured on Monday.
D) The Production division is toured on Tuesday.
E) The Operations division is toured on Wednesday.

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
constraints: Exists([day1:days, day2:days], And(day1 != day2, toured(day1) == Sales, toured(day2) == Sales, Abs(day1 - day2) == 1))

nl_problem.context: A crew of up to five workers is to install a partition in at most three days. The crew completes five tasks in this order: framing, wallboarding, taping, sanding, priming. The crew is selected from the following list, which specifies exactly the tasks each person can do: George: taping Helena: sanding, priming Inga: framing, priming Kelly: framing, sanding Leanda: wallboarding, taping Maricita: sanding Olaf: wallboarding, priming The following conditions must apply: At least one task is done each day. Taping and priming are done on different days. Each crew member does at least one task during the installation, but no more than one task a day. Each task is done by exactly one worker, completed the day it is started and before the next task begins.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the members of the crew?
options: E) George, Helena, Leanda, Maricita, Olaf

declarations: workers = EnumSort([George, Helena, Inga, Kelly, Leanda, Maricita, Olaf])
tasks = EnumSort([framing, wallboarding, taping, sanding, priming])
constraints: ForAll([d:days], Exists([w:workers, t:tasks], does(w, t, d)))
ForAll([w:workers, t1:tasks, t2:tasks, d1:days, d2:days], Implies(And(does(w, t1, d1), does(w, t2, d2), t1 == taping, t2 == priming), d1 != d2))
ForAll([w:workers, t:tasks, d1:days, d2:days], Implies(And(does(w, t, d1), does(w, t, d2)), d1 == d2))
ForAll([w:workers, d:days], Count([t:tasks], does(w, t, d)) <= 1)
ForAll([w:workers, t:tasks], Exists([d:days], does(w, t, d)))
options: is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Or(w == George, w == Helena, w == Inga, w == Kelly)))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Or(w == George, w == Helena, w == Kelly, w == Leanda)))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Or(w == Helena, w == Inga, w == Kelly, w == Olaf)))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Or(w == Helena, w == Inga, w == Maricita, w == Olaf)))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Or(w == George, w == Helena, w == Leanda, w == Maricita, w == Olaf)))

declarations: workers = EnumSort([George, Helena, Inga, Kelly, Leanda, Maricita, Olaf])
tasks = EnumSort([framing, wallboarding, taping, sanding, priming])
constraints: ForAll([d:days], Exists([w:workers, t:tasks], does(w, t, d)))
ForAll([d:days], Not(And(Exists(w1, does(w1, taping, d)), Exists(w2, does(w2, priming, d)))))
ForAll([w:workers], Exists([t:tasks, d:days], does(w, t, d)))
ForAll([w:workers, t:tasks], Count([d:days], does(w, t, d))) <= 1
ForAll([t:tasks], Exists([w:workers, d:days], does(w, t, d)))
ForAll([t:tasks], Count([w:workers, d:days], does(w, t, d)))
options: is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Member(w, Set(George, Helena, Inga, Kelly))))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Member(w, Set(George, Helena, Kelly, Leanda))))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Member(w, Set(Helena, Inga, Kelly, Olaf))))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Member(w, Set(Helena, Inga, Maricita, Olaf))))
is_valid(ForAll([w:workers], Member(w, Set(George, Helena, Leanda, Maricita, Olaf))))

nl_problem.context: A closet contains exactly six hangers—1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6—hanging, in that order, from left to right. The songs are performed consecutively, each on a different one of exactly four instruments: flute, guitar, harmonica, or keyboard. The songs are performed in accordance with the following: The first song performed is not performed on the flute. If "Sammy" is performed on the keyboard, then "Rhino Rock" is performed on the harmonica. If "Question Man" is performed on the keyboard, then "Night's All Right" is performed on the flute. The song performed on the keyboard immediately follows "Rhino Rock" and immediately precedes "Night's All Right."

nl_problem.context: Eight people—Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, and Peter—are sitting, evenly spaced, around a circular picnic table. Any two of them are said to be sitting directly across from one another if and only if there are exactly three other people sitting between them, counting in either direction around the table. The following conditions apply: Fiona sits directly across from George. Harriet sits immediately next to neither Fiona nor Karl. Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the order in which four of the people are seated, with no one else seated between them, counting clockwise around the table?

declarations: people = EnumSort([Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, Peter])
constraints: ForAll([p1:people, p2:people], Implies(clockwise(p1, p2), Not(clockwise(p2, p1))))
ForAll([p1:people, p2:people], Implies(clockwise(p1, p2), Exists([p3:people, p4:people, p5:people], And(clockwise(p1, p3), clockwise(p3, p4), clockwise(p4, p5), clockwise(p5, p2)))))
ForAll([p:people], Implies(Or(p == Fiona, p == Karl), Not(clockwise(Harriet, p))))
And(clockwise(Olivia, Ingrid), Not(Exists([p:people], And(clockwise(Olivia, p), clockwise(p, Ingrid)))))
options: is_sat(And(clockwise(George, Peter), clockwise(Peter, Karl), clockwise(Karl, Fiona)))
is_sat(And(clockwise(Harriet, Olivia), clockwise(Olivia, Ingrid), clockwise(Ingrid, Karl)))
is_sat(And(clockwise(Ingrid, Fiona), clockwise(Fiona, Peter), clockwise(Peter, Manuel)))

The roadster is serviced later in the week than the van and earlier in the week than the hatchback. nl_problem.context: A street entertainer has six boxes stacked one on top of the other and numbered consecutively 1 through 6, from the lowest box up to the highest. Each box contains a single ball, and each ball is one of three colors—green, red, or white. Onlookers are to guess the color of each ball in each box, given that the following conditions hold: There are more red balls than white balls. There is a box containing a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box that contains a red ball. There is a white ball in a box that is immediately below a box that contains a green ball.
nl_problem.question: If there are exactly two white balls, then which one of the following boxes could contain a green ball?

constraints: Count([b:boxes], ball_color(b) == red) > Count([b:boxes], ball_color(b) == white)
Exists([b1:boxes], And(ball_color(b1) == green, ForAll([b2:boxes], Implies(ball_color(b2) == red, b2 > b1))))
Exists([b1:boxes, b2:boxes], And(ball_color(b1) == white, ball_color(b2) == green, b2 == b1 + 1))

declarations: boxes = EnumSort([box1, box2, box3, box4, box5, box6])
constraints: Exists([b:boxes], And(contains(b) == green, ForAll(b2, contains(b2) == red, b < b2)))
Exists([b:boxes], And(contains(b) == white, contains(b1) == green, b1 == b))

nl_problem.context: As part of an open house at a crafts studio, three teachers—Jiang, Kudrow, and Lanning—will give six consecutive presentations on six different subjects. Jiang will present on needlework and origami; Kudrow on pottery, stenciling, and textile making; and Lanning on woodworking. The order of their presentations will meet the following conditions: Kudrow cannot give two presentations in a row. The presentation on stenciling must be given earlier than the one on origami. The presentation on textile making must be given earlier than the one on woodworking.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the order of the presentations, from first to sixth?
options: A) stenciling, origami, needlework, textile making, pottery, woodworking
B) stenciling, origami, pottery, woodworking, needlework, textile making
C) stenciling, origami, textile making, woodworking, needlework, pottery
D) textile making, origami, stenciling, woodworking, needlework, pottery
E) textile making, stenciling, woodworking, needlework, pottery, origami

declarations: subjects = EnumSort([needlework, origami, pottery, stenciling, textile_making, woodworking])
constraints: ForAll([t:teachers, s:subjects], Implies(presents(t, s), Not(ForAll([t2:teachers], presents(t2, s)))))

nl_problem.context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. Within these zones, subzones can be designated for housing, industrial, or retail use, with no subzone designated for more than one use. By city regulation, a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses. The following restrictions are in place: Retail subzones are not allowed in Z1. No more than two subzones for housing are allowed in any particular zone. No more than one retail subzone is allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing. Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following is an allowable way of designating subzones within the three zones?
options: A) Z1: no designated subzones Z2: one housing subzone, two retail subzones Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
B) Z1: one housing subzone, one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
C) Z1: one housing subzone, one retail subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
D) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: three housing subzones Z3: three retail subzones
E) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, two retail subzones

constraints: ForAll([z:zones], Count([u:uses], And(u == housing, designated(z, u))) <= 2)

ForAll([z:zones], Implies(Or(Exists([u:uses], And(u == housing, designated(z, u))), Count([u:uses], And(u == retail, designated(z, u))) == 3), Not(Exists([u:uses], And(u == industrial, designated(z, u))))))

nl_problem.context: A record producer is planning the contents of a CD consisting of a sequence of exactly five instrumental pieces—Reciprocity, Salammbo, Trapezoid, Vancouver, and Wisteria. To create and sustain certain moods, the sequence of pieces will satisfy the following constraints: Salammbo must be earlier than Vancouver. Trapezoid must either be earlier than both Reciprocity and Salammbo or later than both Reciprocity and Salammbo. Wisteria must either be earlier than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid or later than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid.
nl_problem.question: If Wisteria is the first piece on the CD, then which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Trapezoid is the third piece on the CD.
B) Vancouver is the third piece on the CD.
C) Salammbo is the fourth piece on the CD.
D) Vancouver is the fourth piece on the CD
E) Trapezoid is the last piece on the CD.

nl_problem.context: At a business symposium there will be exactly five speakers: Long, Molina, Xiao, Yoshida, and Zimmerman. Each speaker will give exactly one speech, in either the Gold Room or the Rose Room. In each room, there will be exactly one speech at 1 P.M. and one speech at 2 P.M. In one of the rooms, yet to be determined, there will also be a speech at 3 P.M. The schedule of speeches is constrained by the following: Molina's speech must be earlier than Long's, and in the same room. Neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's. If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the speeches given in each room, listed in the order in which they occur?
options: A) Gold Room: Molina's, Long's Rose Room: Zimmerman's, Xiao's, Yoshida's
B) Gold Room: Molina's, Yoshida's, Long's Rose Room: Xiao's Zimmerman's
C) Gold Room: Xiao's, Molina's, Long's Rose Room: Zimmerman's, Yoshida's
D) Gold Room: Yoshida's, Long's, Molina's Rose Room: Zimmerman's, Xiao's
E) Gold Room: Zimmerman's, Molina's Rose Room: Xiao's, Yoshida's, Long's

Implies(schedule(Long)[0] == Gold, And(schedule(Xiao)[0] == Rose, schedule(Zimmerman)[0] == Rose))
options: is_sat(And(schedule(Molina) == [Gold, one], schedule(Long) == [Gold, two], schedule(Zimmerman) == [Rose, one], schedule(Xiao) == [Rose, three], schedule(Yoshida) == [Rose, two]))

is_sat(And(schedule(Xiao) == [Gold, one], schedule(Molina) == [Gold, two], schedule(Long) == [Gold, three], schedule(Zimmerman) == [Rose, one], schedule(Yoshida) == [Rose, two]))

is_sat(And(schedule(Zimmerman) == [Gold, one], schedule(Molina) == [Gold, two], schedule(Xiao) == [Rose, one], schedule(Yoshida) == [Rose, two], schedule(Long) == [Rose, three]))

nl_problem.context: During the seventeenth century, three families—the Trents, the Williamses, and the Yandells—owned the five buildings that constituted the center of their village—the forge, the granary, the inn, the mill, and the stable. Each family owned at least one of the buildings and each building was owned by exactly one of the families. The historical evidence establishes the following about the ownership of the buildings: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge. Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of each family to the building or buildings it owned?
options: A) Trents: the granary, the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge
B) Trents: the granary, the mill Williamses: the inn, the stable Yandells: the forge
C) Trents: the forge, the mill Williamses: the granary, the stable Yandells: the inn
D) Trents: the forge, the granary Williamses: the mill Yandells: the inn, the stable
E) Trents: the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge, the granary

nl_problem.context: A florist is filling a customer's order for three bouquets—bouquet 1, bouquet 2, and bouquet 3. Each of the bouquets is to be composed of one or more of five kinds of flowers—lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, and tulips—subject to the following conditions: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons. If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons. If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies.

nl_problem.context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) slot 1: a finance feature; slot 2: an industry feature; slot 3: a second industry feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a graphic
B) slot 1: a graphic; slot 2: a technology feature; slot 3: a second technology feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a third technology feature
C) slots 1 and 2: a single industry feature; slots 3 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 5: a finance feature
D) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 3: a single industry feature; slot 4: a finance feature; slot 5: a graphic
E) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 3: an industry feature; slot 5: a graphic

constraints: ForAll([i:feature_types], Implies(Exists([s1:slots, s2:slots], And(s1 < s2, features(s1) == i, features(s2) == i)), ForAll([s:slots], Implies(And(s1 < s, s < s2), features(s) == i))))
Implies(Or(Exists([s:slots], features(s) == finance), Exists([s:slots], features(s) == technology)), Exists([s:slots], And(s == 1, Or(features(s) == finance, features(s) == technology))))
options: is_valid(And(features(1) == finance, features(2) == industry, features(3) == null, features(4) == null, features(5) == null))
is_valid(And(features(1) == null, features(2) == technology, features(3) == technology, features(4) == null, features(5) == technology))
is_valid(And(features(1) == null, features(2) == industry, features(3) == industry, features(4) == marketing, features(5) == finance))
is_valid(And(features(1) == technology, features(2) == industry, features(3) == industry, features(4) == finance, features(5) == null))
is_valid(And(features(1) == technology, features(2) == marketing, features(3) == marketing, features(4) == industry, features(5) == null))

The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
nl_problem.question: If an issue of the newsletter has no technology feature and if there is a finance feature that occupies both slots 4 and 5, then which one of the following is required for that issue?
options: A) A finance feature occupies slot 1.
B) A finance feature occupies slot 2 or slot 3 or both.
C) A marketing feature occupies slot 2.
D) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 2.
E) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 3.

constraints: ForAll([i:slots], ForAll([j:slots], Implies(And(i < j, And(occupied_by(i) == f, occupied_by(j) == f)), j == i + 1)))
Implies(Exists([s:slots], occupied_by(s) == finance) Or Exists([s:slots], occupied_by(s) == technology), Exists([s:slots], occupied_by(s) == finance))

declarations: slots = EnumSort([slot1, slot2, slot3, slot4, slot5])
constraints: ForAll([s1:slots, s2:slots], Implies(And(occupied(s1) == occupied(s2), s1 != s2), And(s1 == s2, s1 == s2)))
ForAll([s:slots], Implies(And(occupied(s) == finance, occupied(s) == technology), occupied(s1) == finance))

nl_problem.question: Which one of the following is NOT allowed for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) There is exactly one industry feature, and it occupies slot 1.
B) There is exactly one finance feature, and it occupies slot 2.
C) There is exactly one technology feature, and it occupies slot 3.
D) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 1 is either a finance feature or a marketing feature.
E) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 5 is either an industry feature or a marketing feature.

constraints: ForAll([i:slots], Implies(And(features(i) != null, features(i+1) != null), features(i) == features(i+1)))
ForAll([s:slots], Or(features(s) == finance, features(s) == technology) Implies(features(1) == finance Or features(1) == technology))

is_valid(ForAll([s:slots], Implies(s != 5, Or(features(s) == industry, features(s) == marketing))))

nl_problem.context: Six entertainers—Robinson, Shahpari, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton, and Zane—are being scheduled for the six performances on the opening day of a community festival. Each entertainer will perform at one of six times—in the morning at 9:00 A.M., 10:00 A.M., or 11:00 A.M., or in the afternoon at 2:00 P.M., 3:00 P.M., or 4:00 P.M.—with no two entertainers performing at the same scheduled time. The order in which the entertainers perform is subject to the following constraints: Robinson must perform at some time before Zane. Yeaton's performance must be the next performance after Wu's. Tigay must perform in the afternoon. Zane must perform in the morning.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the order, from first to last, in which the entertainers are scheduled to perform?
options: A) Robinson, Shahpari, Zane, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton
B) Robinson, Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay
C) Robinson, Zane, Tigay, Shahpari, Wu, Yeaton
D) Shahpari, Robinson, Zane, Wu, Tigay, Yeaton
E) Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay, Robinson

declarations: entertainers = EnumSort([Robinson, Shahpari, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton, Zane])
times = EnumSort([nine, ten, eleven, two, three, four])
constraints: ForAll([e1:entertainers, e2:entertainers], Implies(e1 != e2, scheduled(e1) != scheduled(e2)))
options: is_valid(And(scheduled(Robinson) == nine, scheduled(Shahpari) == ten, scheduled(Zane) == eleven, scheduled(Tigay) == two, scheduled(Wu) == three, scheduled(Yeaton) == four))
is_valid(And(scheduled(Robinson) == nine, scheduled(Wu) == ten, scheduled(Yeaton) == eleven, scheduled(Zane) == two, scheduled(Shahpari) == three, scheduled(Tigay) == four))
is_valid(And(scheduled(Robinson) == nine, scheduled(Zane) == ten, scheduled(Tigay) == eleven, scheduled(Shahpari) == two, scheduled(Wu) == three, scheduled(Yeaton) == four))
is_valid(And(scheduled(Shahpari) == nine, scheduled(Robinson) == ten, scheduled(Zane) == eleven, scheduled(Wu) == two, scheduled(Tigay) == three, scheduled(Yeaton) == four))
is_valid(And(scheduled(Wu) == nine, scheduled(Yeaton) == ten, scheduled(Zane) == eleven, scheduled(Shahpari) == two, scheduled(Tigay) == three, scheduled(Robinson) == four))

nl_problem.context: Exactly six of eight ceramic bowls, each crafted by exactly one of eight potters—Larsen, Mills, Neiman, Olivera, Park, Reigel, Serra, and Vance—will be displayed in a row in positions consecutively numbered 1 through 6, one bowl per position. The display is subject to the following conditions: If Larsen's bowl is displayed, Mills's bowl cannot be displayed. Park's bowl can be displayed only if it is next to Olivera's bowl and next to Serra's bowl. Reigel's bowl can be displayed only in either position 1 or position 6. Serra's bowl cannot be displayed in either position 2 or position 4. Neiman's bowl can be displayed only in position 5.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the display of bowls, listed by potters name, in order from position 1 through position 6?
options: A) Larsen, Mills, Serra, Park, Olivera, Reigel
B) Larsen, Neiman, Olivera, Park, Serra, Vance
C) Mills, Olivera, Park, Serra, Reigel, Vance
D) Reigel, Park, Serra, Olivera, Neiman, Mills
E) Serra, Park, Olivera, Vance, Larsen, Reigel

constraints: Implies(Exists([pos:positions], displayed(Larsen) == pos), Not(Exists([pos:positions], displayed(Mills) == pos)))

Implies(Exists([pos:positions], displayed(Park) == pos), And(Exists([pos:positions], displayed(Olivera) == pos + 1 Or displayed(Olivera) == pos - 1), Exists([pos:positions], displayed(Serra) == pos + 1 Or displayed(Serra) == pos - 1)))

nl_problem.context: In one week—Monday through Friday—a library's bookmobile will visit five of the following six neighborhoods—Hidden Hills, Lakeville, Nottingham, Oldtown, Park Plaza, and Sunnyside. Exactly one neighborhood will be visited on each of the five days, and none of the neighborhoods will be visited on more than one day. The bookmobile's schedule must conform to the following conditions: Hidden Hills is visited, but not on Friday. If Oldtown is visited, then it is visited on the day immediately before Hidden Hills is visited. If Lakeville is visited, then it is visited on Wednesday. Nottingham and Sunnyside are both visited, but not on consecutive days.
nl_problem.question: If Hidden Hills is visited on Wednesday, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Nottingham is visited on Monday.
B) Oldtown is visited on Tuesday.
C) Park Plaza is visited on Friday.
D) Sunnyside is visited on Monday.
E) Sunnyside is visited on Thursday

declarations: days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
neighborhoods = EnumSort([Hidden_Hills, Lakeville, Nottingham, Oldtown, Park_Plaza, Sunnyside])
constraints: ForAll([n1:neighborhoods, n2:neighborhoods], Implies(n1 != n2, visited(d1) != visited(d2)))
And(visited(Nottingham), visited(Sunnyside), visited(d1) != visited(d2 + 1), visited(d2) != visited(d1 + 1))

declarations: neighborhoods = EnumSort([HiddenHills, Lakeville, Nottingham, Oldtown, ParkPlaza, Sunnyside])

nl_problem.context: Six park rangers—Jefferson, Koguchi, Larson, Mendez, Olsen, and Pruitt—are each to be assigned to monitor one of three areas—area 1, area 2, and area 3—in a national park. At least one ranger, but no more than three, is assigned to each area. The assignment must conform to the following conditions: Mendez is assigned to area 3. Neither Olsen nor Pruitt is assigned to area 1. Larson is assigned to the same area as either Koguchi or Mendez but not to the same area as both. If Olsen is assigned to area 2, then Jefferson is assigned to the same area as Koguchi; otherwise, Jefferson is assigned to a different area than Koguchi.

C) area 1: Koguchi, Pruitt; area 2: Jefferson; area 3: Larson, Mendez, Olsen
D) area 1: Jefferson, Koguchi, Larson; area 2: Mendez, Olsen; area 3: Pruitt
E) area 1: Jefferson, Koguchi, Larson; area 2: Olsen, Pruitt; area 3: Mendez

nl_problem.context: An economics department is assigning six teaching assistants—Ramos, Smith, Taj, Vogel, Yi, and Zane—to three courses—Labor, Markets, and Pricing. Each assistant will be assigned to exactly one course, and each course will have at least one assistant assigned to it. The assignment of assistants to courses is subject to the following conditions: Markets must have exactly two assistants assigned to it. Smith and Taj must be assigned to the same course as each other. Vogel and Yi cannot be assigned to the same course as each other. Yi and Zane must both be assigned to Pricing if either one of them is.

is_sat(And(assigned(Smith) == Pricing, assigned(Taj) == Pricing, assigned(Yi) == Pricing))

nl_problem.context: There are exactly six computers—P, Q, R, S, T, and U—on a small network. Exactly one of those computers was infected by a virus from outside the network, and that virus was then transmitted between computers on the network. Each computer received the virus exactly once. The following pieces of information concerning the spread of the virus have been established: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network. S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network. The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S. Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q. Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
nl_problem.question: One possible route of the virus from the first computer in the network infected to Q is
options: A) from R to P to T to Q
B) from T to S to R to Q
C) from T to S to U to Q
D) from U to P to R to Q
E) from U to T to P to R to Q

declarations: computers = EnumSort([P, Q, R, S, T, U])
constraints: ForAll([c:computers], infected(c) Implies Exists([c2:computers], transmits(c2, c)))
options: is_valid(And(transmits(R, P), transmits(P, T), transmits(T, Q)))
is_valid(And(transmits(T, S), transmits(S, R), transmits(R, Q)))
is_valid(And(transmits(T, S), transmits(S, U), transmits(U, Q)))
is_valid(And(transmits(U, P), transmits(P, R), transmits(R, Q)))
is_valid(And(transmits(U, T), transmits(T, P), transmits(P, R), transmits(R, Q)))

declarations: computers = EnumSort([P, Q, R, S, T, U])
options: is_valid(And(transmitted(R, P), transmitted(P, T), transmitted(T, Q)))

is_valid(And(transmitted(T, S), transmitted(S, U), transmitted(U, Q)))

nl_problem.context: There are exactly six computers—P, Q, R, S, T, and U—on a small network. Exactly one of those computers was infected by a virus from outside the network, and that virus was then transmitted between computers on the network. Each computer received the virus exactly once. The following pieces of information concerning the spread of the virus have been established: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network. S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network. The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S. Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q. Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
nl_problem.question: Which one of the following could be the computer that was infected from outside the network?
